sentence: C allouses and manicures -- that's one way to depict Lowe's Cos.' opportunities for continued growth in 2016.
The home-improvement retailer long has attracted women shoppers, with its focus on appliances and customer service.
But analysts sayLowe's ( LOW ) andHome Depot ( HD ) can nail additional growth by better addressing the "pro market" -- contractors and building trade customers.
Brent Kirby holds the title of Lowe's chief omni-channel officer, which means he oversees all the company's selling channels, including the avenue that sells to professionals.
He sees a vast opportunity there.
"We think the U.S. pro market is well over $3 billion annually," he told IBD.
Kirby isn't the only one who sees such potential.
Credit Suisse analyst Seth Sigman told IBD he likes the opportunities on that side of the business.
"We're positive on (Lowe's) and (Home Depot)," he said.
According to the Leading Indicator of Remodeling Activity, annual spending growth for home improvements will accelerate to 6.8% in the second quarter of 2016 from 2.4% in 2015's fourth quarter.
A group within the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University does the forecast.
The National Association of the Remodeling Industry supports that, saying 58% of the remodelers it surveyed in December are expecting first-quarter growth in their businesses.
Lowe's has seen strong financial gains due to the rebounding housing market and economic recovery.
For the quarter ended Oct. 30, Lowe's reported net earnings of $736 million, up 25.8% over the same period a year ago.
Diluted earnings per share rose 35.6% to 80 cents from 59 cents in the year-earlier quarter.
Sales for the period rose 5% to $14.4 billion from $13.7 billion in 2014's third quarter.
The company has been returning cash to shareholders: It paid $260 million in dividends in the third quarter.
And as of the end of October, Lowe's operated 1,849 stores in the U.S., Canada and Mexico.
In January 2012, Lowe's was trading at roughly 26 a share, and the stock's price has steadily risen over the past four years.
It hit an all-time high of 78.13 in November, and even with the major downturn in markets this January, the stock still hovers around 68.
Brian Nagel, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., has an outperform rating on Lowe's.
He says the continued recovery in the U.S. housing market is resulting in stronger demand for home improvement products.
To attract more building pros, Lowe's has been investing in staff and technology.
Kirby says the company has both national and local account reps to serve pros.
He says each store has a dedicated service desk for pros.
Lowe's also completed its Lowesforpros.com website last summer.
It enables pro users to set up custom catalogs for products they buy frequently, Kirby says.
"We're getting really good feedback on the website," he said.
"There's plenty of opportunity (to serve) pros and we're excited (about capturing it)."
The company is also investing in other digital properties: websites, modeling programs, and apps for phones, tablets and desktops.
On Jan. 14, it announced that it will hire 46,000 seasonal employees to help with the busy spring and summer seasons, 6,000 more than last year.
Some, however, remain hesitant.
Laura Champine, an analyst with Cantor Fitzgerald, has a hold on the company.
She's seen a lot of growth in the stock, as well as that of Home Depot's, over the past year.
She notes that Lowe's lags Home Depot in same-store sales growth, but it's very strong in appliances, particularly with women.
"Lowe's has more selection in appliances and cares a lot about the category," Champine told IBD.
"They got the reputation as a women's store (a decade ago), whereas Home Depot (had the reputation) of selling drywall to guys.
That stereotype still holds true to some extent."
The company's Kirby isn't exactly arguing the point.
"We certainly recognize that the female shopper makes many decisions in the home-improvement space," he said.
He says Lowe's "bright stores" and "clean functioning displays" appeal to female buyers.
"We have the largest assortment of appliance brands in our stores," he added.
"We've also put a big focus on making a great customer experience online, with the ability to spin appliance images 360 degrees, or the ability to open a refrigerator."
Market pollster TraQline says Lowe's had 20% of the U.S. appliance market in units sold for the quarter ended Sept. 30, its most recent data.
That's up from 18.8% in the comparable year-earlier quarter.Sears ( SHLD ) had 26.5% and Home Depot had 13.5%, up from 13.3% in the year-earlier quarter.
But, Sears' unit share declined from 28.6% in the year-earlier quarter, which means most of its lost business is ending up at Lowe's.
"Lowe's close rate also is increasing; they're doing a better job of getting people to actually buy the products once they're in the stores," Eric Voyer, vice president at TraQline, told IBD.
Added Oppenheimer's Nagel: "Lowe's has done a better job on merchandising appliances and the fashion home, but Home Depot has been catching up the last couple of years."
Lowe's is also investing in "interior specialists."
Kirby says it currently has these design professionals in 1,365 stores and will put them in its remaining stores this year.
They go out to customers' homes and assess a project, like a kitchen or bath remodel, and then put together a design for the space.
They also work with third-party contractors to complete the work.
"We continue to work to establish ourselves as the project authority," Kirby said.
Lowe's already has exterior projects specialists in all of its stores, he adds.

Cantor's Champine notes that Lowe's and Home Depot face a challenge from Menards, a private home-improvement retailer with roughly 300 stores based in Eau Claire, Wis. Menards is being "very aggressive with price points" in the Midwest, she said.
Still, the pricey and bulky products Lowe's and other home improvement companies sell help to insulate them from more online competition.
"The performance gap, against other retail categories, has grown," said Credit Suisse's Sigman.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
